It reacts to outside influence to survive, and it retreats where necessary. As my friend I_M_Qwerty so astutely points out, the proposed deft re-management of the Social Security system was more akin to your 401(k) than it was any government control. Like your 401, SS funds would have been invested by experts in their field given the current expected rate of return and based on its marginal risk for breakeven. Where the bell curve begins to hedge, T-Bills are utilized (or similar). It's all about speculation. This doesn't scare investors as it is flexible, there is accountability, and long-term investments are almost always a surety. It differs from the current bailout packages in that the stability of the international dollar is now in question. Banks leverage against foreign funds to protect their capital, whereas the proposed changes to SS would not have. When you "give" money to a bank, you are, in essence, loaning money to your best friend that just lost all his money at the Blackjack table for the 5th time this week. If you have 5 friends and 1 needs $100 to pay his cable bill, how likely are you and the other 4 to each kick in a $20 bill if that friend in need wasted all his money instead of paying his bill? That is the stock market. And that is their reaction to the bank bailouts. But SS reform was different. While it was indeed irresponsibly managed and spent, the idea was to change money handlers. That is, you may be willing to commit your $20 to your friend, but only if you pay his bill for him or you use his responsible mother and give HER the money. In other words, one is about accountability for funding. That was the SS reformat. The other is faith that money won't be used irresponsibly by the same friend that abused it before. That is a bailout that occurs twice. So, they are not the same -- not by a long shot -- and investors have lost faith in the money handlers and are choosing to pay their own bills. And those leveraged against their investments, the smaller investors, are paying the price as confidence erodes, which drives the circle that is both consumer confidence and consumer spending. The dollar value tanks, so while you're still paying 99 cents for a loaf or bread, that 99 cents-by-effort-dollar yesterday is now $1.50-by-effort-dollar today. When you "give" money to a bank, you are, in essence, loaning money to your best friend that just lost all his money at the Blackjack table for the 5th time this week. If you have 5 friends and 1 needs $100 to pay his cable bill, how likely are you and the other 4 to each kick in a $20 bill if that friend in need wasted all his money instead of paying his bill? That is the stock market. And that is their reaction to the bank bailouts. But SS reform was different. While it was indeed irresponsibly managed and spent, the idea was to change money handlers. That is, you may be willing to commit your $20 to your friend, but only if you pay his bill for him or you use his responsible mother and give HER the money. In other words, one is about accountability for funding. That was the SS reformat. The other is faith that money won't be used irresponsibly by the same friend that abused it before. That is a bailout that occurs twice. So, they are not the same -- not by a long shot -- and investors have lost faith in the money handlers and are choosing to pay their own bills. And those leveraged against their investments, the smaller investors, are paying the price as confidence erodes, which drives the circle that is both consumer confidence and consumer spending. The dollar value tanks, so while you're still paying 99 cents for a loaf or bread, that 99 cents-by-effort-dollar yesterday is now $1.50-by-effort-dollar today. And people stop buying bread unless they have to. Are you baiting me, sweetie? It's not that there is no God or that He isn't listening. You're probably just asking the wrong questions.
